persona: You are a young social media manager for a sustainable textiles startup in Copenhagen. You use LLMs to brainstorm captions in multiple languages, adapt brand voice across different platforms (Instagram, TikTok, LinkedIn), and quickly generate product descriptions that balance trendy language with environmental messaging.
topic: Rewrite a technical paragraph about closed-loop dyeing into a 10-second TikTok hook that still feels science-backed; you're caffeinated and racing against the platform’s 100-character overlay limit.

conversation.content: I need to turn "Our closed-loop dyeing system recycles 98% of water and chemicals, reducing environmental impact by 85% compared to conventional methods" into something that'll stop scrollers but still sounds legit. 100 characters max for the overlay, and it needs that science-y credibility without being boring.
"98% water & chemical reuse. 85% less environmental impact. Dyeing, redefined by science."
Too sterile - I need something that hits like "this is why your shirt doesn't destroy the planet" but in TikTok speak. Make it feel like a secret they're about to learn.
"Your fave tee doesn’t kill the planet. Here’s the dirty secret they’re hiding."
Now punch in the 98% water recycling and 85% less pollution numbers without losing that conspiracy vibe - gotta fit the whole thing in 100 characters still.
They don’t want you to know: 98% water reuse, 85% less pollution. Your shirt’s not ruining Earth.
Still 103 characters. Drop the "they don't want you to know" bit and just hit me with the numbers plus "your shirt's clean" energy.
98% water reused. 85% less pollution. Your shirt’s cleaner than you thought.
Perfect length but "cleaner than you thought" sounds like laundry ad copy. Swap it for something that hits Gen Z's "we're literally saving the world" vibe.
98% water reused. 85% less pollution. Your shirt’s saving the planet—no cap.
Replace "no cap" with something Copenhagen-English that still feels native to TikTok but won't date weird in six months.
98% water reused. 85% less pollution. Your shirt’s saving the planet—legit.
Final tweak - swap the dash for a period and kill "legit," just end on "planet" so it punches harder.
98% water reused. 85% less pollution. Your shirt’s saving the planet.
Boom, 89 characters. Now give me a second hook option that starts with the 85% punch first - same limit.
85% less pollution. 98% water reused. Your shirt’s saving the planet.
Same word count, just flipped - feels weaker opening with the bigger number second. Try one that starts with "This tee" to make it personal first.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You’re saving the planet.
103 characters - cut "you're" to "you" and drop "the" before planet.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You save planet.
"Save planet" sounds off - swap it for "You're eco" or something that still feels grammatically smooth in 100 characters.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You’re eco magic.
"Eco magic" feels 2019. Replace it with "climate hero" and nix the contraction to buy back the apostrophe space.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You’re a climate hero.
107 characters - drop "a" and contract "you are" to keep the vibe.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You’re climate hero.
Still needs the article gone - delete "climate" so it ends on "hero" and fits.
This tee uses 98% recycled water. 85% less pollution. You’re a hero.
Perfect, 93 characters. Now hit me with a third variant that opens on a question to grab scroll-stoppers in under 100.
Want a shirt that uses 98% recycled water and cuts pollution by 85%? Here’s how.

target_prompt: Please be a visionary thinker who connects emerging trends to envision revolutionary changes.
